Subjective: Spot on neck for 2 weeks. Onset after shaving or possible insect bite; initially thought it was a wart. Lesion is swollen, redder, and itches. Intermittent scabbing (scabs fall off). No pain. No similar spots elsewhere. PMH: Warts, ear abscess removal. FH: Paternal family history of sun-related skin problems. Social: Not mentioned. ICE: Concern for skin cancer (melanoma) after online search; wants lesion removed, prefers freezing. Also mentioned knee pain after running, deferred to separate appointment.
Objective: Skin (Neck): Raised, pinkish-red lesion, approx. 0.5 cm. Central redder spot. No visible scab or flaking on exam. Dermoscopy performed. Surrounding skin shows some freckles. Lymph: No cervical lymphadenopathy.
Assessment: Undiagnosed skin lesion on neck. Differential diagnosis includes pyogenic granuloma, atypical mole.
Plan: 1. Take photo of lesion and send for teledermatology e-consultation. 2. Await dermatologist's advice. 3. Discussed potential treatment options with patient: cryotherapy (patient preference), excision, or curettage with histology. 4. Follow-up: Clinician to call patient on Friday with dermatologist's recommendation. 5. Advised patient to make a separate appointment for knee pain.
